metadata.metaValue: Initialize the segmentation, output a 2D array.

Implementation of the Centripetal Catmull-Rom spline. 
source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centripetal_Catmull-Rom_spline


- parameterization: Define the knot parameterization of the curve, where 0=Uniform, 0.5=Centripetal, and 1=Chordal.

- samples: Define the number of samples for each segment of the strand.

- is_closed: Define if the curve is closed for the computation.

- ctrl_points: the control points in which the strand pass through.

Work-around for the first and last segment of the curve (if open)

The CatRom formula only returns "t" between p1 and p2. 
In the case of an open curve, you need to save the first inPoint as both p0 and p1 for the first segment, the same goes for the last inPoint being saved as p2 and p3.
Because of this, it creates NaN in the computation because 2 points share the same position.
To avoid this, we mirror the next / last point in array from the first / last inPoints.

Init input points:

Depending on multiple conditions, we prepare an array for each segment so that the data are ready for the solver.
Because of the structure of the centripetal Catmull-Rom formula, we actually set the first point to p0 and p1, and p2 and p3 for the last, for the first and last segment of an open curve.
For each segment, output an array composed of p0, p1, p2, p3

Init input points:

Depending on multiple conditions, we prepare an array for each segment so that the data are ready for the solver.
Because of the structure of the centripetal Catmull-Rom formula, we actually set the first point to p0 and p1, and p2 and p3 for the last, for the first and last segment of an open curve.

Work-around for the first and last segment of the curve (if open)

The CatRom formula only returns "t" between p1 and p2. 
In the case of an open curve, you need to save the first inPoint as both p0 and p1 for the first segment, the same goes for the last inPoint being saved as p2 and p3.
Because of this, it creates NaN in the computation because 2 points share the same position.
To avoid this, we mirror the next / last point in array from the first / last inPoints.

Manually push the last segment ( if the curve is closed ).
For closed curve, we use the second-last and last array elements as p0 and p1, then, the first & second elements as p2 and p3.
Add Last Segment on closed curve
Set curve's debug color:   green = uniform // blue = centripetal // red = chordal

Convert segments 2D array back into a 1D array

Manually add last point on open curve
solve the centripetal Cattmull-Rom spline formula
